questions.stem: According to Craik and Lockhart's (1972) levels of processing framework, which of the following encoding strategies would produce the STRONGEST and most durable long-term memory trace?

options.text: Judging whether words are printed in uppercase or lowercase letters (structural encoding)
Determining whether words rhyme with a target word (phonemic encoding)
Deciding whether words fit meaningfully into a sentence (semantic encoding)
Counting the number of syllables in each word (phonemic encoding)

questions.explanation: Craik and Lockhart's levels of processing framework posits that deeper processing produces more durable memory traces. Structural encoding (physical features like case) is the shallowest level. Phonemic encoding (sound features like rhyming or syllable counting) is an intermediate level. Semantic encoding (meaning-based processing like fitting words into sentences) represents the deepest level and produces the strongest, most durable memory traces. This hierarchy -- structural < phonemic < semantic -- is a core EPPP concept.

questions.stem: A student studying for the EPPP reads the definition of 'proactive interference' and then generates her own example of how previously learned Spanish vocabulary interferes with learning French. This study strategy is best described as:

options.text: Maintenance rehearsal
Elaborative rehearsal
Massed practice
Structural encoding

questions.explanation: Elaborative rehearsal involves connecting new information to existing knowledge, generating examples, and thinking about meaning. This student is engaging in elaborative rehearsal by creating a personal example that links the concept of proactive interference to her own language-learning experience. Maintenance rehearsal would involve simply rereading or repeating the definition without engaging with its meaning. Massed practice refers to concentrated study in a single session. Structural encoding involves attending only to surface-level physical features.

questions.stem: Godden and Baddeley's (1975) classic experiment with scuba divers demonstrated that words learned underwater were best recalled underwater, and words learned on land were best recalled on land. This finding is an example of:

options.text: State-dependent memory
Context-dependent memory
The generation effect
Transfer-appropriate processing

questions.explanation: Context-dependent memory refers to the finding that recall is improved when the external environment at retrieval matches the environment present during encoding. The underwater vs. land manipulation is a change in the external physical context, making this context-dependent memory. State-dependent memory involves matching internal physiological or psychological states (e.g., mood, drug state). The generation effect relates to actively producing information. Transfer-appropriate processing concerns matching the type of processing at encoding and retrieval.

questions.stem: The transfer-appropriate processing principle (Morris, Bransford, & Franks, 1977) refines the levels of processing framework by demonstrating that:

options.text: Semantic encoding always produces superior memory regardless of test type
Memory performance depends on the match between encoding processes and retrieval demands
Shallow processing produces stronger memories than deep processing in all conditions
Maintenance rehearsal is more effective than elaborative rehearsal for long-term retention

questions.explanation: Transfer-appropriate processing demonstrates that memory performance depends on the match between the type of processing at encoding and the type demanded at retrieval. Semantic encoding produces superior performance on meaning-based tests, but phonemic encoding may actually produce better performance on rhyme-recognition tests. This refines the levels of processing framework by showing that 'deeper' is not always 'better' -- what matters is the congruence between how information was encoded and how it is tested.

questions.stem: Research by Roediger and Karpicke (2006) on the testing effect demonstrated that students who were tested on material one week after initial learning showed significantly better retention than students who:

options.text: Used elaborative interrogation techniques during the same period
Spent the equivalent time restudying the same material
Used spaced retrieval practice over the same interval
Generated their own examples and mnemonics

questions.explanation: The testing effect (also called retrieval practice) is one of the most robust findings in learning science. Roediger and Karpicke (2006) demonstrated that practicing retrieval through testing produced substantially better long-term retention than restudying the same material for an equivalent amount of time. Each act of retrieval strengthens the memory trace and makes information more accessible for future recall. Spaced retrieval practice (testing + spacing combined) actually produces even better results than testing alone.

questions.stem: Select all factors that are consistent with Paivio's (1971) dual coding theory and its implications for memory enhancement.

options.text: Information encoded in both verbal and imaginal systems creates two retrieval routes
Concrete words paired with vivid mental images are more memorable than abstract words encoded only verbally
The method of loci leverages spatial-visual associations to enhance ordered recall
Verbal encoding is always superior to imaginal encoding regardless of material type
Single-code representation in one system is more efficient than dual-code representation

questions.explanation: Dual coding theory (Paivio, 1971) proposes that information stored in both the verbal and imaginal coding systems creates two independent retrieval routes, making it more memorable. Concrete words paired with images benefit from dual coding and are recalled better than abstract words encoded only verbally. The method of loci creates vivid spatial-visual associations that leverage the imaginal system alongside verbal encoding. The theory specifically argues that dual-code representation is superior to single-code, not the reverse.

questions.stem: Select all statements that accurately describe the encoding specificity principle and its applications.

options.text: Memory is most effective when retrieval conditions match encoding conditions
Context-dependent memory demonstrates that matching external environments enhances recall
State-dependent memory shows that matching internal physiological states enhances recall
The principle predicts that retrieval cues are unnecessary because all memories are equally accessible
The principle was proposed by Ebbinghaus as part of his forgetting curve research

questions.explanation: The encoding specificity principle (Tulving & Thomson, 1973) states that memory is most effective when retrieval conditions match encoding conditions. Context-dependent memory (matching external environments, as in Godden & Baddeley's scuba diver study) and state-dependent memory (matching internal states such as mood or drug state) are both applications of this principle. The principle emphasizes the importance of retrieval cues that match encoding conditions. It was proposed by Tulving and Thomson, not Ebbinghaus (who studied the forgetting curve).

questions.stem: Select all study strategies that research has consistently shown to be HIGHLY effective for long-term retention.

options.text: Spaced retrieval practice (testing distributed over time)
Elaborative interrogation (asking 'why' and 'how' questions about the material)
Passive rereading of highlighted text
Active self-testing with flashcards or practice questions
Massed practice (cramming all material into a single session)

questions.explanation: Research consistently supports spaced retrieval practice as the most effective strategy for long-term retention, combining the testing effect with the spacing effect. Elaborative interrogation promotes deep semantic processing. Active self-testing leverages the testing effect. In contrast, passive rereading produces only moderate results and creates an 'illusion of learning,' and massed practice (cramming) produces low long-term retention despite potentially adequate short-term performance.

questions.stem: Select all accurate descriptions of encoding failure as a cause of forgetting.

options.text: Information was never adequately encoded into long-term memory in the first place
The classic penny experiment demonstrates that most people cannot draw penny details despite frequent exposure
It is particularly relevant to understanding memory complaints in individuals with attentional disorders
It occurs when previously stored memories are degraded by the passage of time
It results from competing memories blocking access to the target memory at retrieval

questions.explanation: Encoding failure occurs when information never enters long-term memory because it was not attended to or processed at sufficient depth. The penny experiment demonstrates this: despite seeing thousands of pennies, most people never deeply encoded the specific visual details. This is particularly relevant for individuals with ADHD or attentional disorders, whose 'memory problems' often reflect encoding/attentional deficits rather than retrieval failures. Decay over time (option D) and retrieval blocking by competing memories (option E, describing interference) represent different forgetting mechanisms.

questions.stem: Select all accurate statements about the self-reference effect and the generation effect in memory research.

options.text: Information encoded in relation to oneself is remembered better than information encoded semantically
Actively generating information produces better memory than passively reading it
Completing 'Proactive inter_____' produces better memory than reading 'Proactive interference'
The self-reference effect produces weaker encoding than shallow structural processing
The generation effect shows that passive exposure always outperforms active production

questions.explanation: The self-reference effect demonstrates that encoding information in relation to oneself (e.g., 'Does this word describe you?') produces superior recall even compared to semantic processing. The generation effect shows that actively producing information (e.g., completing word fragments) leads to better memory than passively reading the same information. Both effects support active, personally relevant encoding strategies. The self-reference effect produces stronger, not weaker, encoding than structural processing. The generation effect specifically shows that active production outperforms passive exposure.

questions.stem: Match each encoding/memory phenomenon with the researcher(s) most closely associated with it.
questions.explanation: Craik and Lockhart (1972) proposed the levels of processing framework, arguing that memory durability depends on depth of encoding (shallow/structural vs. deep/semantic). Tulving and Thomson (1973) articulated the encoding specificity principle, stating that retrieval is best when conditions match those at encoding. Paivio (1971) developed dual coding theory, proposing separate verbal and imaginal coding systems. Ebbinghaus (1885) was the first to document the spacing effect through his pioneering self-experimentation with nonsense syllables and the forgetting curve.

questions.stem: Match each mnemonic strategy with its correct description.

columns.text: Grouping individual items into larger meaningful units to increase STM capacity
Associating items with locations along a familiar mental route
Linking the sound of an unfamiliar word to its meaning through a concrete image
Associating items with a pre-memorized sequence of rhyming cue words

questions.explanation: The method of loci involves mentally placing items at specific locations along a familiar route (e.g., your house), creating vivid spatial-visual associations for ordered recall. The keyword method creates a concrete image linking an unfamiliar word's sound to its meaning through an intermediary keyword, particularly effective for foreign language learning. The pegword method uses a pre-memorized set of rhyming cue words (e.g., 'one is a bun, two is a shoe') for learning numbered lists. Chunking groups individual items into meaningful larger units to effectively increase short-term memory capacity.

questions.stem: For each type of rehearsal or processing, select ALL accurate characteristics.

columns.text: Involves simple repetition without engaging meaning
Connects new information to existing knowledge
Attends to physical appearance of stimuli

questions.explanation: Maintenance rehearsal involves simple repetition without engaging meaning, producing minimal long-term retention. Elaborative rehearsal connects new information to existing knowledge and produces durable long-term memory traces. Shallow (structural) processing attends to physical features such as uppercase/lowercase letters or font type. Deep (semantic) processing involves attending to meaning and making connections, producing the most durable memory traces. Both elaborative rehearsal and deep semantic processing involve meaningful engagement and produce strong long-term memories.

questions.stem: For each memory phenomenon, select ALL situations where it would be expected to enhance recall.

columns.text: Studying and testing in the same physical room
Being in the same mood during study and test
Taking practice tests rather than rereading notes
Distributing study over multiple sessions across days

questions.explanation: Context-dependent memory predicts enhanced recall when the external physical environment matches between encoding and retrieval (same room). State-dependent memory predicts enhanced recall when internal states match (same mood, same pharmacological state). The testing effect shows that practicing retrieval through self-testing produces better long-term retention than passive restudying. The spacing effect demonstrates that distributing study sessions over time produces superior retention compared to massed practice in a single session.

The transfer-appropriate processing principle (Morris, Bransford, & Franks, 1977) refines this by showing that the 'best' encoding strategy depends on the match between encoding and retrieval demands -- phonemic encoding may outperform semantic encoding on a rhyme-recognition test.

Spaced retrieval practice -- combining spacing with testing -- produces the optimal long-term retention of all known study strategies. questions.stem: A therapist is working with a combat veteran with PTSD who reports difficulty accessing traumatic memories during calm therapy sessions but experiences vivid, intrusive recollections during high-stress situations. Identify the contributing factors, central principle, and clinical implications.

options.text: Traumatic memories were encoded during high-arousal physiological states
Internal state mismatch between encoding (high stress) and retrieval (calm therapy)
The patient has complete encoding failure for the traumatic events
Structural encoding during the trauma produced shallow, fragile memory traces
State-dependent memory
The spacing effect
The generation effect
Therapeutic techniques that gradually reintroduce arousal cues may facilitate memory access
Insights gained in calm therapy sessions may be harder to retrieve during distressed states
The memories are permanently inaccessible and cannot be therapeutically addressed
Increasing the number of study sessions will resolve the memory access problem

questions.explanation: This scenario illustrates state-dependent memory: traumatic memories encoded during high-arousal states are more accessible when the individual is in a similar high-arousal state, but difficult to access during the calm conditions of therapy. The contributing factors are the high-arousal encoding context and the mismatch between encoding and retrieval states. Clinically, this means techniques that carefully and gradually reintroduce arousal cues (as in exposure therapy) may facilitate memory access. Conversely, therapeutic insights gained in session may be harder to retrieve when the patient is distressed outside of therapy.

questions.stem: An older adult patient reports 'terrible memory' and states that she can never find where she left her keys, phone, or glasses. Upon evaluation, the neuropsychologist finds that her memory retrieval abilities are within normal limits for her age. Identify the contributing factors, central explanation, and clinical implications.

options.text: Divided attention at the time of placing objects prevents adequate encoding
Objects are placed during routine, automatic behavior without deliberate processing
Hippocampal degeneration has eliminated declarative memory capacity
Retroactive interference from new memories has erased the stored locations
Encoding failure due to insufficient attention during initial placement
Retrograde amnesia affecting recently formed memories
Age-related dementia with progressive memory loss
Teaching the patient to use deliberate attention and verbal labeling when placing objects
Distinguishing encoding failures from retrieval failures has important diagnostic implications
Immediate referral for Alzheimer's disease screening is the only appropriate next step
Prescribing cholinesterase inhibitors to restore hippocampal function

questions.explanation: This case illustrates encoding failure: the patient's 'memory problems' actually reflect attentional deficits at the time of encoding rather than retrieval failures. When placing objects during routine, automatic behavior with divided attention, the location is never adequately encoded into memory. Since retrieval testing is normal, this is not dementia or hippocampal damage. Clinically, teaching deliberate attention strategies (e.g., verbal labeling: 'I am placing my keys on the counter') can improve encoding. Distinguishing encoding failures from retrieval failures has important diagnostic implications for differentiating normal age-related complaints from pathological memory disorders.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding the spacing effect and distributed practice.
questions.passage: Research on study strategies has yielded important findings for learning optimization. [The spacing effect demonstrates that distributing study sessions over time produces superior long-term retention compared to massed practice]. [Cramming (massed practice) is the most effective strategy for long-term retention]. [The spacing effect was first documented by Ebbinghaus in 1885 and is one of the most replicable findings in experimental psychology]. [The optimal inter-study interval depends on the retention interval -- for a test one week away, spacing sessions 1-2 days apart is optimal]. [Rereading material multiple times in a single sitting produces stronger long-term memories than spaced retrieval practice]. [Spaced retrieval practice (combining testing with spacing) produces the strongest retention of all study strategies].

highlightableSegments.text: The spacing effect demonstrates that distributing study sessions over time produces superior long-term retention compared to massed practice
Cramming (massed practice) is the most effective strategy for long-term retention
The spacing effect was first documented by Ebbinghaus in 1885 and is one of the most replicable findings in experimental psychology
The optimal inter-study interval depends on the retention interval -- for a test one week away, spacing sessions 1-2 days apart is optimal
Rereading material multiple times in a single sitting produces stronger long-term memories than spaced retrieval practice
Spaced retrieval practice (combining testing with spacing) produces the strongest retention of all study strategies

questions.explanation: The spacing effect is well-established: distributed practice produces superior long-term retention compared to massed practice (cramming). Ebbinghaus first documented this in 1885, and it remains one of the most replicable findings in psychology. The optimal inter-study interval scales with the retention interval. Cramming is NOT the most effective strategy -- it produces low long-term retention despite sometimes adequate short-term performance. Rereading is moderate at best and creates an illusion of learning. Spaced retrieval practice (testing + spacing) produces the strongest retention of all.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe state-dependent memory and its clinical relevance.
questions.passage: State-dependent memory has important implications for clinical practice. [Recall is enhanced when an individual's internal physiological or psychological state at retrieval matches the state during encoding]. [State-dependent memory has been demonstrated with mood states, pharmacological states, and arousal levels]. [Traumatic memories encoded during high-arousal states may be difficult to access during the calm conditions of a therapy session]. [State-dependent memory refers exclusively to matching the external physical environment between encoding and retrieval]. [Substance-related memories may be more accessible under the influence of the same substance due to state-dependent effects]. [State-dependent memory effects are strongest for recognition memory tests and weakest for free recall].

highlightableSegments.text: Recall is enhanced when an individual's internal physiological or psychological state at retrieval matches the state during encoding
State-dependent memory has been demonstrated with mood states, pharmacological states, and arousal levels
Traumatic memories encoded during high-arousal states may be difficult to access during the calm conditions of a therapy session
State-dependent memory refers exclusively to matching the external physical environment between encoding and retrieval
Substance-related memories may be more accessible under the influence of the same substance due to state-dependent effects
State-dependent memory effects are strongest for recognition memory tests and weakest for free recall

questions.explanation: State-dependent memory involves matching internal physiological or psychological states between encoding and retrieval, not external environments (which is context-dependent memory). It has been demonstrated with mood, drugs, and arousal levels. It has important clinical implications: traumatic memories encoded during high arousal may be hard to access in calm therapy, and substance-related memories may be more accessible under the influence. Research actually shows state-dependent effects are typically stronger for free recall than recognition, as recognition provides more retrieval cues that can overcome state mismatches.

questions.stem: Arrange the following encoding strategies from LEAST effective to MOST effective for long-term retention, based on research evidence.

items.text: Passive rereading of highlighted text
Massed practice (cramming) with maintenance rehearsal
Elaborative interrogation (asking 'why' and 'how' questions)
Active retrieval practice (self-testing) in a single session
Distributed practice (spacing study sessions over time)
Spaced retrieval practice (testing combined with spacing)

questions.explanation: Research consistently ranks these strategies from least to most effective: Passive rereading is least effective, creating an 'illusion of learning.' Massed practice with maintenance rehearsal produces low long-term retention. Elaborative interrogation promotes deeper processing and is moderately to highly effective. Active retrieval practice (testing effect) is very effective even in a single session. Distributed practice (spacing effect) produces high long-term retention. Spaced retrieval practice -- combining the testing effect with the spacing effect -- produces the optimal long-term retention of all known study strategies.

questions.stem: Arrange the following levels of processing from SHALLOWEST to DEEPEST according to Craik and Lockhart's (1972) framework.

items.text: Structural encoding: judging whether a word is in uppercase or lowercase letters
Orthographic encoding: noticing the visual pattern and letter arrangement of a word
Phonemic encoding: determining whether a word rhymes with another word
Semantic encoding: deciding whether a word fits meaningfully into a sentence
Self-referential encoding: deciding whether a word describes you personally
Elaborative encoding: generating personal examples and connecting to multiple existing memories

questions.explanation: Craik and Lockhart's framework arranges processing from shallow to deep: Structural encoding (physical features like letter case) is shallowest. Orthographic encoding (visual letter patterns) is slightly deeper but still surface-level. Phonemic encoding (sound properties like rhyming) is intermediate. Semantic encoding (meaning-based processing) represents deep processing. Self-referential encoding goes even deeper by connecting information to the self (the self-reference effect). The deepest level involves elaborative encoding that generates personal examples and creates multiple connections to existing knowledge, producing the most durable memory traces.

questions.stem: A cognitive psychology researcher compares three study strategies over a 30-day retention period. Group A uses massed rereading (cramming), Group B uses distributed rereading (spaced study), and Group C uses spaced retrieval practice. All groups study the same material for the same total amount of time. Percent correct on a recall test is measured at days 1, 7, 14, 21, and 30.
questions.question: What pattern in the data best supports the combined effectiveness of the spacing and testing effects?

options.text: Massed rereading produces higher initial performance but rapid decline, while spaced retrieval practice produces slightly lower initial scores but dramatically better long-term retention
Both groups show identical patterns of forgetting over the 30-day period
Massed rereading produces superior performance at every time point measured
Spaced retrieval practice shows worse performance than cramming at all time points

questions.explanation: The data illustrates a classic finding: massed practice (cramming) produces higher initial performance (72% vs. 65% on Day 1) because information is temporarily accessible in short-term memory. However, massed practice shows rapid forgetting (dropping to 12% by Day 30). Spaced retrieval practice starts slightly lower but shows dramatically superior long-term retention (48% at Day 30 vs. 12%). This demonstrates why cramming creates an 'illusion of learning' -- it feels effective in the short term but produces poor long-term outcomes. The combined spacing + testing effects produce the most durable memories.

questions.stem: A researcher measures recall performance on a word list task as a function of processing depth. Participants encode 50 words using either structural, phonemic, or semantic processing. Recall is tested immediately and after a 24-hour delay.
questions.question: Which conclusion is best supported by the data?

options.text: Structural encoding produces the most durable memories at all retention intervals
Deeper semantic processing produces both higher initial recall and more resistant-to-forgetting memory traces compared to shallower processing levels
All three encoding levels produce equivalent recall after a 24-hour delay
Phonemic encoding produces the strongest memories because sound-based traces are more durable

questions.explanation: The data clearly demonstrates the levels of processing effect: semantic encoding produces the highest recall both immediately (68%) and after 24 hours (55%), with the smallest proportional decline. Phonemic encoding is intermediate (42% immediate, 22% delayed). Structural encoding produces the lowest recall at both time points (25% immediate, 8% delayed) with the steepest proportional decline. This pattern shows that deeper processing produces not only stronger initial encoding but also more forgetting-resistant memory traces, exactly as Craik and Lockhart's (1972) framework predicts.

questions.stem: Categorize each memory phenomenon as an example of context-dependent memory, state-dependent memory, or encoding failure.

items.text: A scuba diver recalls more words learned underwater when tested underwater
A person cannot draw the details of a penny despite seeing thousands of them
Information learned while intoxicated is better recalled while intoxicated again
A student who studied in the library performs better when tested in the library
A person with ADHD cannot remember where they placed their keys due to divided attention
Traumatic memories are more vivid when the person is in a similar emotional state

questions.explanation: Context-dependent memory involves matching external physical environments: the scuba diver study (Godden & Baddeley) and studying/testing in the same library both demonstrate this. State-dependent memory involves matching internal states: information learned while intoxicated being better recalled while intoxicated again (pharmacological state match) and traumatic memories being more vivid during similar emotional states (mood/arousal state match). Encoding failure means information was never adequately encoded: the penny experiment (never deeply processed despite exposure) and the ADHD key-placement scenario (divided attention prevented encoding).

questions.stem: Categorize each example as demonstrating either the self-reference effect, the generation effect, or the testing effect (retrieval practice).

items.text: Asking 'Does this word describe you?' produces better recall than 'Does this word mean the same as [synonym]?'
Completing 'Proactive inter_____' produces better memory than reading 'Proactive interference'
Taking practice quizzes produces better long-term retention than rereading the textbook
Relating a psychological concept to a personal experience from one's own life enhances recall
Creating one's own flashcards rather than reading pre-made study notes
Repeatedly attempting to recall material from memory rather than re-exposing oneself to it

questions.explanation: The self-reference effect involves encoding information in relation to oneself: asking whether a word describes you or relating concepts to personal experiences. The generation effect involves actively producing information rather than passively receiving it: completing word fragments or creating one's own flashcards. The testing effect (retrieval practice) involves actively retrieving information from memory: taking practice quizzes or repeatedly attempting recall rather than rereading. All three effects support active, engaged encoding over passive exposure.
